author: Kaja Whitehouse
title: Comic-book artists claim Iron Man ripped off their ideas | New York Post
text:
A pair of comic-book artists may have found ​a secret weakness in superhero-factory Marvel’s legal armor.
A Manhattan federal judge OK’d a sliver of a copyright lawsuit by graphic ​artists Ben and Ray Lai — who have accused Disney and Marvel of ripping off their company, Horizon Comics, when it revived “Iron Man” for the big screen.
Judge Paul Oetken tossed the bulk of the lawsuit, which claimed that the Iron Man ​character — as revived for film — was basically a copycat of the Lai brothers’ ​”​Radix​”​ character, who is also a futuristic fighter wearing full-body armor.
But the judge allowed a smaller claim by the Lai brothers to move forward involving an “Iron Man 3” movie poster featuring a kneeling Robert Downey Jr. as the armored superhero. That poster, and one featuring Radix in a similar pose, shared a “similarity of expression” sufficient survive Marvel and Disney’s motion to dismiss, the judge said.
The Lai brothers said they created their Radix character in 2001 at a time when Iron Man, who first appeared in 1963, was still “wearing simple spandex-like attire and minimal armor.”
“It was not until after the Lai brother’s submitted their work in Radix … that Marvel began depicting Iron Man wearing the suits,” their lawsuit claimed. ​​
Judge Oetken agreed that the two characters had similarities, but he said that there were too many differences to let overall copyright claim move forward.
Judge Oetken also tossed that claim because of the barrier to copyrighting something as broad as a mechanized suit of armor.
A lawyer for the defendants, which also includes Paramount Pictures Corp., declined to comment.
